subject: Art
title: Sequential Art & Comics
description: Telling stories across multiple panels â€” the grammar of comics.

hook.text: Panel 1: a door. Panel 2: a hand reaches for the handle. Panel 3: the door opens to reveal... Sequential art tells stories through the GAPS between images. What happens between panels is where the reader's imagination does the work.

buildup.text: The 'gutter' (space between panels) is where time passes. The reader's brain fills in the action. Panel-to-panel transitions: moment-to-moment (slow), action-to-action (normal pacing), scene-to-scene (time jump), aspect-to-aspect (mood building).

discovery.text: Panel size communicates pacing: small panels = fast, staccato (action sequences). Large panels = slow, contemplative (establishing shots, emotional moments). A full-page spread = maximum impact, pause, the reader STOPS.

twist.text: Comics are the only art form where the reader controls time. In film, the director controls pacing. In comics, the reader can linger on a panel, flip back, or rush ahead. The layout guides but doesn't force the pace.

climax.text: Tell a simple story in 6 panels: try an establishing shot, action, close-up reaction, consequence, and resolution. Vary panel sizes to control pacing. You'll discover that the gutter between panels is the most powerful storytelling tool.

punchline.text: Comics don't show everything â€” they show just enough. The reader's imagination creates the movie between the frames.

quiz.question: What is the 'gutter' in sequential art and why is it important?
options: It's the space between panels where the reader's imagination fills in the action and time passes
